content.description: This ascends a great finger crack. It does not have anchors on it, but it looks like it's been cleaned up quit a bit. Climb this perfect finger crack for about 20 feet, and find a dirty gear belay.
content.location:
This is in the notch between Junk Yard Dog and

Jimmy "Superfly" Snuka

.

content.description:
This is high up on a big shelf, the same one that many of the other routes are on.

It is the large, left-facing dihedral just to the climber's right of the final pitch of

Piece Snatchers

. Feel free to post the FAist if you know.
content.location:
It ascends the large, left-facing dihedral towards the top of the wall. It is climber's right of the final pitch of

Piece Snatchers

.

content.description:
Climb the start of

Jimmy "Super Fly" Snuka

, and move left on the shelf and directly under the anchors of The Ultimate Warrior. Climb up towards the anchors on thin, balancy moves and a low angle mantel. Finish on finger tips and smear stemming. It may be bolted in the future for a true free send.
content.protection: It is a TR only at this point.
content.location:
This is on the upper section of SW Quarry Wall just left of

Jimmy "Super Fly" Snuka

.

content.description: Locate a fixed rope at the base of the upper ledge. The anchors for this line are just below the tree anchor. Rappel to a ledge, TR, or pull the line and lead it. The climbing is mostly stemming and a few awkward moves with good small gear. It is still quite dirty.
content.protection: Small stoppers, 2x cams 0.3-0.4, and a #0.75 to a #2.
content.location: This is below the Upper Shelf and is best approached from above. Use the fixed rope to safely approach the anchors.

climbs.name: Razor Ramon
climbs.fa: Mike Robinson, Stu Salinas, Mary Anderson 6/21

content.description: Thin fingers, stemming, and shoulder scums got me up this. The gear is just good enough, but there are a few spots that a fall is likely to pull out gear to the next piece. If you onsight 10 finger crack in Unaweep, then you should be fine.
content.protection: RRs, Stoppers, and 2x cams to a #2.
content.location:
This is between

Jake "The Snake" Roberts

and

Piece Snatcher

. Start at the base of the cliff.

climbs.name: Piece Snatcher
climbs.fa: not in the old guidebook? Rob Pizem?

content.description:
This may be one of the most prominent lines on The Quarry Wall. Currently, it is a bit dirty like some other classics on this wall but is well worth doing and is an excellent option on hot summer days.

P1. Start at the big pine tree climber's right of the old "active quarry", and climb the crack system past a tree and onto a ledge and good belay spot, 100 feet.

P2. Walk left and climb up to the left side of a tree on a large ledge.

P3. Traverse right to the base of a large, left-facing dihedral.

P4. Climb the dihedral.
content.protection: Stoppers and 2x rack to #2 and a single #4.
content.location:
Start at the top of the wash/old "active quarry".

-Other markers are: the large pine tree, boulders at the top of the cliff, and a clear crack system that trends right into a final, left-facing dihedral.

-This terminates just right of the cliff top boulders.

content.description:
We climbed this today, because we didn't feel like jugging. It is harder than it looks, and finishing to the left gave up a couple of OK moves to top out.

Belay off a tree, and hike out.
content.location: This is the climber's rightmost line on the Upper Ledge.

content.description: The whole thing is cruxy. Climb squeeze and OW moves to the anchors. Continue up the second half of Junk Yard Dog or rap from here.
content.location:
Hike past the top of

Piece Snatcher

to a broken, left-facing dihedral, and lower 80 feet to a big ledge. LBM is climber's right of the dihedral/Junk Yard Dog.

content.description: Start with a shoulder stand. Mantel on a hand-sized shelf, and work your way up on thin edges and friction moves.
content.location:
This is just right of

"Rowdy Roddy" Piper

.

content.description: This is another short but good chimney that offers a chance for small placements which makes this easy to climb with a standard rack to a #3.
content.location:
This is climber's right of

Honkey Tonk Man

and

Jerry "The King" Lawler

.

climbs.name: Junkyard Dog
climbs.fa: Mike Robinson, Stu Salinas, Mary Anderson 6/21

content.description: Climb a chimney for 30 feet to a ledge. Then climb the wide fist crack/offwidth to a sporty mantel and into a final, flaring hand crack. Finish at a ledge with anchors, 35 feet.
content.location:
This climb is on the climber's right of the small notch with

Unknown .4 Crack

and climber's left of

Little Big Man

.

content.description: This has two distinct cruxes. They are at the first bolt and in the corner above the second bolt. This has excellent climbing with a combination of sport and trad like movement. This can be set up as a toprope and/or simply used as a rap station to gain the ledge below.
content.location: This is left of the dirty dihedral that Junk Yard Dog is on. Locate the first bolt 15 feet up and a shallow dihedral above that which terminates at a small, triangular roof. Move right just below the roof, and continue up the corner on hands.

content.description: Climb the dirty corner with small placements on harder-than-it-looks climbing.
content.protection: Small stoppers and a singles rack #0.3 to #3.
content.location:
This is climber's right 20 feet and slightly up from

Little, Big Man

.

content.description: Start on the shallow, left-facing dihedral on thin corner moves. Then follow the left-trending roof on wide gear with the opportunity to sling a chockstone. Follow the line as the roof turns into a left-facing dihedral for the final 20 feet. Belay at a tree.
content.protection: 2x cams to a #3 with extra #4-6s plus stoppers.
content.location:
This is the obvious line climber's right of

Piece Snatcher

.

content.description: Honkey Tonk Man is a good warm-up for the other two OWs in this area. This has good gear on secure moves.
content.location:
This is just to the climber's right of

Little, Big Man

.

content.description: We did it just because it's there... it is a fun, little slab.
content.location: Just below the notch with the splitter finger crack is a low angle dike that can be toproped.

content.description: I thought this would go, then I didn't. After cleaning it up, we where able to find that it does go! This turns out to be a really fun route with several hidden holds that seem to appear just as you want them. Use all techniques to get up this. Thin sport moves, jams, stemming, and body scums will come into play.
content.location:
This route starts at the bottom of the SW Quarry Wall. It is 50 feet to the climber's right of

Piece Snatcher

. P1. Look for the Elephant face dihedral, and climb 50 feet to a ledge. Belay here to reduce drag on the second 50 feet. From the belay, traverse climber's left, pull a bulge, then follow the roof into a corner and to the top (50 feet).

content.description:
This one reminds me of some of the thin slab routes out in New Hampshire.

It has micro-edges, friction moves, and sharp crimps with the occasional "good stance" to clip.
content.location:
Start just right of

Jimmy "Superfly" Snuka

, and finish at the anchors to the right.

content.description:
Currently this is just a toprope that one can do after climbing

King Kong Bundy

. Climb the left-facing corner to the anchors.
content.location:
It is just right of

King Kong Bundy

and uses the same anchor.
